prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Summarized Context:
The witness Lamiroir describes what she saw at in the room at the backstage when she took a peek from the entrance door.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Phoenix Wright
Description: A pianist who can't play a lick. Formerly an ace defense attorney of some renown.
Character 1
Name: Trucy Wright
Description: Future star magician, and Phoenix Wright's daughter. Fond of her Mr. Hat trick.
Character 2
Name: Klavier Gavin
Description: Star prosecutor and leader/vocalist for the rock group, the Gavinners.
Character 3
Name: LeTouse
Description: Lamiroir's interpreter. His first name is "Romein".
Character 4
Name: Lamiroir
Description: Singer lauded as the "Siren of the Ballad", from the tiny country of Borginia.
Character 5
Name: Machi Tobaye
Description: Lamiroir's favorite pianist. He is blind.
Character 6
Name: Ema Skye
Description: Detective obsessed with forensics. In charge of the initial investigation.
Character 7
Name: Daryan Crescend
Description: Guitarist for the Gavinners. His day job is as a detective in Criminal Affairs, Div. 3.
Character 8
Name: Valant Gramarye
Description: Famous magician, often on TV. Fond of exaggeration.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: How long did I yearn for one of these? Just putting it on makes me feel... ready.
Evidence 1
Name: Postcard
Description: Lamiroir's own publicity postcard. Click here for details.
Evidence 2
Name: Lyrics Sheet
Description: Contains the lyrics to Lamiroir's ballad. Click here for details.
Evidence 3
Name: Investigation Request
Description: Information concerning the crime to be restricted to police and related parties.
Evidence 4
Name: Brooch
Description: Found at the crime scene. Seems strangely familiar... Found at the crime scene. Turns out it belongs to Lamiroir.
Evidence 5
Name: Revolver
Description: The murder weapon.  A deadly, high-caliber revolver. The murder weapon. A deadly, high-caliber revolver belonging to Mr. LeTouse.
Evidence 6
Name: Key Ring
Description: Mr. LeTouse died clutching this. Note the heart-shaped ring. Found in the victim's left hand. Holds keys to a guitar case and a motorcycle.
Evidence 7
Name: Mixing Board
Description: Allows music to be played in separate tracks. Click here to use.
Evidence 8
Name: LeTouse's Autopsy Report
Description: Death due to loss of blood from a gunshot wound. Est. time of death: 9:00-9:30 PM.
Evidence 9
Name: Crime Photo
Description: Victim shot in shoulder in Lamiroir's room. [caption] The victim was lying head down on the floor, his face turned to the left. There is smeared writing in blood on the floor in front of his head next to his right hand.
Evidence 10
Name: Diagram
Description: The crime scene was Lamiroir's dressing room. [caption] Observing from the door, the victim was blocked from sight by items. There was a gun next to the victim's body. Two bullet holes were found on the wall where the door was.
Evidence 11
Name: Video Tape
Description: Taped recording of Lamiroir's performance. Click here for details.
Evidence 12
Name: Headset
Description: Retrieved from Backstage Hallway. Receiver/transmitter for voice signals. All concert staff wore one. Receiver/transmitter for voice signals with a 30-foot range. All concert staff wore one.
Evidence 13
Name: Switch → Remote Trigger
Description: Found on the stage. It's a switch for something, and that's about all I know. Found on the stage. Triggers an igniter. Use with caution. Found on the stage. Triggers an igniter within 30 feet.
Evidence 14
Name: Forum Diagram
Description: Cross-section diagram of the Sunshine Coliseum. Click here for details.
Evidence 15
Name: Igniter
Description: Found at the crime scene. Emits a flame when triggered by remote control. Identical igniters in Gavin's guitar and at the crime scene. Triggered by "Remote Trigger".
Evidence 16
Name: Borginian Newspaper
Description: Article about the case. It doesn't mention the lyrics of Lamiroir's ballad.
Evidence 17
Name: Prosecutor Gavin's Guitar
Description: A gift from Lamiroir, sent from Borginia. Burned the night of the concert.
Evidence 18
Name: Replica
Description: Replica of something, held by Mr. LeTouse. Apparently the focus of his investigation. Borginia Cocoon replica, held by Mr. LeTouse. Replica of a cocoon from which a remedy for "incuritis" may be extracted.
Evidence 19
Name: Newspaper Article
Description: Article about the Chief Justice's son, who is inflicted with "incuritis".
Evidence 20
Name: Burnt Fragments
Description: Found at the crime scene, bearing a gunpowder residue. Possibly a firecracker?

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: As for what I saw... I saw nothing.
Person: Lamiroir
Testimony 1
Testimony: That night, I was invited to sing on stage, and this I did.
Person: Lamiroir
Testimony 2
Testimony: I did not return backstage after the second set.
Person: Lamiroir
Testimony 3
Testimony: When my performance was finished, I went backstage for just a moment...
Person: Lamiroir
Testimony 4
Testimony: I saw nothing. The late Mr. LeTouse's body was behind a wall.
Person: Lamiroir
Testimony 5
Testimony: I saw bullet holes in the wall, and knew Mr. LeTouse had been shot...
Person: Lamiroir
Testimony 6
Testimony: Then I was led by the police to Mr. Gavin's dressing room, and told to wait there.
Person: Lamiroir
Testimony 7
Testimony: That was where I learned that something had happened... But I wasn't told the details.
Person: Lamiroir

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
response:
Okay, let's try to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. So, the user provided a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies, mostly from Lamiroir. The task is to find one pair where the evidence contradicts a testimony.

First, I'll start by going through each of Lamiroir's testimonies and see if any of them clash with the evidence provided.

Looking at the testimonies:

Testimony 0: "As for what I saw... I saw nothing."
Testimony 1: She was invited to sing and did so.
Testimony 2: She didn't return backstage after the second set.
Testimony 3: After her performance, she went backstage for a moment...
Testimony 4: She saw nothing because the body was behind a wall.
Testimony 5: She saw bullet holes and knew LeTouse was shot.
Testimony 6: She was led to Gavin's room by police.
Testimony 7: She learned something happened there but wasn't told details.

Now, the key here is to find a testimony that conflicts with evidence. Let's check the evidences.

Looking at the evidence list, Evidence 9 is the Crime Photo, which describes the victim lying head down with smeared writing in blood next to his right hand. Evidence 10 (Diagram) mentions that from the door, the victim was blocked by items, and there were two bullet holes in the wall where the door was. Evidence 5 is the Revolver, which was LeTouse's. 

Testimony 5 says Lamiroir saw bullet holes in the wall and knew LeTouse was shot. However, according to the Diagram (Evidence 10), the bullet holes were on the wall where the door was, meaning they would be visible from the entrance. But the Diagram also says that the victim's body was blocked from sight by items when viewed from the door. So, if Lamiroir only peeked from the entrance, she could see the bullet holes but not the body. But how did she know LeTouse was shot? Because seeing bullet holes doesn't necessarily mean he was shot unless she saw the body. However, Testimony 4 says she didn't see the body because it was behind a wall (blocked by items). So there's a contradiction here. She claims to have deduced he was shot by the bullet holes, but according to the crime scene layout, the body wasn't visible. However, the Revolver (Evidence 5) is LeTouse's, but maybe that's not directly related.

Wait, Evidence 9's Crime Photo also mentions smeared writing in blood next to the victim's right hand. If LeTouse was shot and wrote something, maybe that's a clue. But how does that tie into Lamiroir's testimony?

Wait, let's re-examine Testimony 3: She went backstage for just a moment after her performance. Testimony 2 says she didn't return after the second set. But if the performance was the second set, then Testimony 3 might be referring to a different time. Hmm, maybe not the main contradiction.

Wait, the key contradiction might be between Testimony 4 and Testimony 5. Testimony 4 says she saw nothing (the body was behind a wall), but Testimony 5 says she saw bullet holes and knew he was shot. However, according to Evidence 10 (Diagram), the bullet holes were on the wall by the door. So she could see the bullet holes from the entrance. But how did she know that the bullet holes meant LeTouse was shot? Unless she saw the body, which she claims she didn't. But maybe there's another angle.

Wait, Evidence 5 is the Revolver, which belonged to LeTouse. If she saw the revolver, that might indicate a shooting, but she didn't mention seeing the gun. According to Evidence 10, the gun was next to the victim's body. Since the body was blocked from view, she wouldn't see the gun either. So how did she know LeTouse was shot? The bullet holes alone don't necessarily mean someone was shot. Maybe she heard the gunshots? But that's not part of her testimony here.

Alternatively, looking at Evidence 9 (Crime Photo) which mentions the victim's right hand next to the smeared writing. If the victim was shot, perhaps he wrote something. But Lamiroir's testimony 5 says she knew he was shot because of the bullet holes. However, according to the Diagram (Evidence 10), the bullet holes were in the wall by the door. So if she saw the bullet holes from the entrance, that could be possible. But how does that contradict her testimony? Maybe there's a contradiction in the timing or visibility.

Wait, the Diagram (Evidence 10) states that from the door, the victim's body was blocked by items. So if Lamiroir peeked from the entrance (door), she couldn't see the body but could see the bullet holes on the wall. Then in Testimony 5, she says she saw bullet holes and knew LeTouse was shot. But how would she know it was LeTouse who was shot if she couldn't see the body? Unless she assumed it, but maybe that's not a direct contradiction. But perhaps she couldn't have seen the bullet holes if the items blocking the body also blocked the view of the wall? Wait, the Diagram says the bullet holes were on the wall where the door was. So the entrance door's wall had two bullet holes. If she entered and saw the bullet holes on the same wall as the door, maybe that's possible. But how does that contradict her testimony?

Wait, Testimony 4 says she saw nothing (the body was behind a wall). Testimony 5 says she saw bullet holes. But according to the Diagram, the bullet holes were on the wall where the door was, which she could see when entering. So those two testimonies might not contradict each other. She could see the bullet holes (Testimony 5) but not the body (Testimony 4). Then where's the contradiction?

Alternatively, maybe another angle: the Revolver (Evidence 5) belongs to LeTouse. If the murder weapon was his own gun, but Lamiroir might not know that. But how does that tie into her testimony?

Wait, let's check Testimony 3: "When my performance was finished, I went backstage for just a moment..." Then Testimony 2 says she didn't return after the second set. But maybe there's a contradiction in timing. Wait, the performance in Testimony 1 is the first set, then after finishing, she went backstage (Testimony 3). Testimony 2 says she didn't return backstage after the second set. But the murder happened during the time when she went backstage after her performance. The time of death is 9-9:30 PM (Autopsy Report, Evidence 8). If her performance was during the second set, but Testimony 2 says she didn't return after the second set. Wait, perhaps the timing is conflicting. Let me check.

But this might be more complex. Let's think of another approach. Let's look for a testimony that directly contradicts a piece of evidence.

For example, Testimony 4: "I saw nothing. The late Mr. LeTouse's body was behind a wall." But according to the Crime Photo (Evidence 9), there's smeared writing in blood next to his right hand. If she entered the room, maybe she could see that writing, but she claims she saw nothing. But according to the Diagram (Evidence 10), the body was blocked by items when viewed from the door. So she couldn't see the body or the writing. So that might not be a contradiction.

Wait, but Evidence 9's caption says the victim was lying head down, face turned left, with smeared writing in front of his head next to his right hand. If the items blocking the view of the body also blocked the view of that area, then she couldn't see the writing. So no contradiction here.

Alternatively, Testimony 5: she saw bullet holes and knew LeTouse was shot. But the Revolver (Evidence 5) is LeTouse's. So if the gun was his, perhaps the shooter used his own gun, but how does that tie into her testimony?

Wait, maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 4 and the Diagram. Testimony 4 says the body was behind a wall, but the Diagram (Evidence 10) says the body was in the room but blocked by items, not a wall. Wait, the Diagram's caption says "the victim was blocked from sight by items. There was a gun next to the victim's body. Two bullet holes were found on the wall where the door was." So the items blocked the view of the body from the door. So when Lamiroir looked in from the door, she couldn't see the body because of the items, not a wall. But Testimony 4 says "the body was behind a wall." That's a contradiction. Because according to the Diagram, it's blocked by items, not a wall. So if Lamiroir says the body was behind a wall, but the actual layout shows it was blocked by items, that's a contradiction. Therefore, Testimony 4 contradicts Evidence 10.

But wait, the Diagram's caption says "blocked from sight by items," but Testimony 4 says "behind a wall." That's conflicting. So the testimony claims the body was behind a wall (a structural part of the room), but the evidence says it was blocked by items (like furniture or objects). Therefore, Testimony 4 is contradicted by Evidence 10.

So the pair would be Evidence 10 (Diagram) and Testimony 4.

Alternatively, let's check another angle. Testimony 3 says she went backstage for a moment after her performance. Then, Testimony 2 says she didn't return backstage after the second set. So maybe the timing is conflicting if her performance was part of the second set. But without more info on the timing of the sets, this is unclear.

Alternatively, looking at Testimony 5: she saw bullet holes and knew LeTouse was shot. But if the bullet holes are on the wall by the door (Evidence 10), and the victim was shot in the shoulder (Crime Photo, Evidence 9), then the bullet holes in the wall could be from the shots that hit him. But how does that contradict? Maybe if the bullet trajectory doesn't align. For example, the victim was shot in the shoulder, but the bullet holes in the wall would be from bullets passing through or missing. But unless there's evidence about the trajectory, this might not be directly contradictory.

Wait, the Revolver (Evidence 5) is the murder weapon, a high-caliber revolver. If two bullet holes are in the wall (Evidence 10), and the victim was shot once (as per the Autopsy Report, Evidence 8: death from a gunshot wound), then there's an extra bullet hole. So maybe two shots were fired: one hit the victim, one hit the wall. But how does this tie into Lamiroir's testimony? She saw the bullet holes and deduced LeTouse was shot. But if there were two bullet holes, maybe she saw both and concluded he was shot, but how does that contradict?

Alternatively, maybe the key contradiction is that Lamiroir claims she saw bullet holes (Testimony 5) and thus knew LeTouse was shot, but according to the Diagram (Evidence 10), the bullet holes were on the wall by the door, which she could see when entering. However, the Revolver (Evidence 5) was found next to the body, which was blocked by items. So she couldn't see the gun, but she could see the bullet holes. That's not a contradiction unless there's evidence that the bullet holes couldn't have been seen from the door.

Wait, but according to the Diagram (Evidence 10), the bullet holes were on the wall where the door was. So when she entered or peeked in from the door, she would see the bullet holes on that wall. Therefore, her seeing them is possible. So that's not a contradiction.

Hmm. Let's think again. The user wants one pair where evidence and testimony contradict. Let's look for the most direct contradiction.

Testimony 4: "I saw nothing. The late Mr. LeTouse's body was behind a wall." But according to Evidence 10 (Diagram), the body was in the same room, blocked by items when viewed from the door, not behind a wall. So the testimony mentions a wall blocking the view, but the evidence says items blocked the view. Therefore, Testimony 4 contradicts Evidence 10. So {"evidence": 10, "testimony":4}.

Alternatively, Testimony 5 says she saw bullet holes and knew he was shot. But Evidence 10 says there were two bullet holes on the wall by the door. So if she saw the bullet holes, that's correct, but how did she know it was LeTouse? Unless she saw the body, which she didn't. But that's an inference, not a direct contradiction. The contradiction would be if she couldn't have seen the bullet holes. But according to the Diagram, she could. So no contradiction there.

Another angle: Testimony 3 says she went backstage after her performance. If the crime happened around 9 PM (time of death 9-9:30), and her performance was during that time, then perhaps she was there at the time of the murder. But how does that contradict evidence? The Revolver belongs to LeTouse, but she might not know that.

Wait, the Brooch (Evidence 4) is Lamiroir's and was found at the crime scene. If she was there, maybe she left it, but her testimony says she went backstage briefly. But unless the evidence shows she was there longer, that's not a direct contradiction.

Another thought: Evidence 6 (Key Ring) was found in the victim's left hand. The Crime Photo (9) mentions smeared writing in blood next to his right hand. If the victim was holding the keys in his left hand and writing with his right, that's plausible. Not a contradiction.

Wait, Testimony 0: "As for what I saw... I saw nothing." But other testimonies (like 5) say she saw bullet holes. So Testimony 0 contradicts Testimony 5. But the question is about evidence contradicting testimony, not testimony contradicting testimony. So that's not applicable here.

So going back to the initial thought: Testimony 4 says the body was behind a wall, but Evidence 10 says the body was blocked by items in the same room. Therefore, the testimony incorrectly states a wall was blocking the view, while the evidence shows it was items. Therefore, Evidence 10 contradicts Testimony 4.

{"evidence": 10, "testimony": 4}

response:
Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. So, we need to find which evidence and testimony from Ema contradict each other. The user wants just one pair, so I need to look through each testimony and see if any of the evidence directly contradicts it.

First, let's list out Ema's testimonies:

Testimony 0: Machi stole the body because of lyrics.
Testimony 1: He moved the body to match Lamiroir's song.
Testimony 2: No one in this country had a motive to kill the victim.
Testimony 3: Machi left his signature at the scene.
Testimony 4: All evidence points to the defendant (probably Machi?).
Testimony 5: The shooter was blind.

Now, looking at the evidence. Let's check each testimony against the evidence.

Starting with Testimony 3: "Machi practically left his signature at the scene." What would be Machi's signature? He's a blind pianist. If there's evidence related to blindness or something unique to him. Now, Evidence 5 is the Revolver, which belongs to LeTouse. If the shooter was blind, maybe the shot placement would be different? Or maybe something else.

But Testimony 5: shooter was blind. However, Evidence 15 (Igniter) is linked to the Remote Trigger (Evidence 13) which has a 30-foot range. If the shooter used a remote trigger, maybe they didn't need to see? But that's not directly conflicting.

Wait, Testimony 3 says Machi left his signature. If Machi is blind (Character 5: Machi Tobaye is blind), then maybe the testimony is implying that the shooter being blind is his signature. But Testimony 5 states the shooter was blind, which would align with Machi. However, if there's evidence that contradicts the shooter being blind, then that would conflict.

Looking at Evidence 9: the crime photo shows the victim shot in the shoulder. The smeared writing in blood next to his right hand. Also, Evidence 10: Diagram shows two bullet holes on the wall where the door was. If the shooter was blind, maybe the accuracy would be off. But a blind person might not aim well, but how does that contradict?

Alternatively, Evidence 15: Igniter found at the crime scene is identical to the one in Gavin's guitar. The Remote Trigger (13) has a 30-foot range. If the shooter used a remote trigger, they might not need to be present. But that's more about method than the shooter's blindness.

Wait, Testimony 5 says the shooter was blind. But if the revolver (Evidence 5) belonged to LeTouse, and the Key Ring (6) has keys to a guitar case and motorcycle. Maybe the actual shooter wasn't blind but used a different method. Alternatively, if the shooter needed to see to use the revolver, but a blind person wouldn't aim properly. However, the fact that there are two bullet holes on the wall (Evidence 10) might indicate multiple shots. A blind shooter might fire multiple times, but that's speculative.

Alternatively, consider Testimony 2: "No one in this country had a motive." But Evidence 18 is the Borginian Cocoon replica related to "incuritis" remedy. The victim was holding that, and LeTouse was investigating it. The newspaper (19) talks about the Chief Justice's son having incuritis. So maybe the motive is related to that, which is from Borginia. Since LeTouse is from Borginia (since he's Lamiroir's interpreter, and she's from Borginia), the motive could be international. So Evidence 18 and 19 would contradict Testimony 2, which claims no local motive. That's a possible contradiction. So Evidence 18 or 19 contradicts Testimony 2.

But the user asked for one pair. Let me check. Testimony 2 says no one in this country (the country where the crime happened, not Borginia) had a motive. But if the replica (Evidence 18) and the newspaper (19) indicate that the motive is related to Borginia's cocoon and the disease, then the killer's motive could be from Borginia, but the testimony says no local motive. So if the killer is from another country, that aligns, but if the evidence shows that the victim had something related to Borginia's interests, maybe someone from Borginia had a motive. But the testimony says "no one in this country" (the country where the crime occurred) had a motive. If the killer is from another country (like Borginia), that's possible. But the evidence points to the defendant (Machi, who is from Borginia?), but according to the characters, Machi is Lamiroir's pianist and Borginian. So if the defendant is Machi, who is from Borginia, but the testimony says no local (non-Borginian) had a motive. Then the motive would be from Borginia, which is not in "this country". So maybe Testimony 2 is correct. Wait, but the evidence 18 and 19 suggest that the motive is related to the cocoon and the disease, which is a Borginian matter. So the killer (Machi) might have a motive from Borginia, which is not local. So Testimony 2's claim that no local had a motive is correct. Then maybe that's not a contradiction.

Wait, but the problem is that the testimony says no one in this country had a motive, but if the evidence shows that the murder was related to Borginian matters, then perhaps the real killer is from Borginia (like Machi) and thus the motive isn't local. So that testimony would be accurate. So maybe that's not a contradiction.

Back to Testimony 3: "Machi left his signature at the scene." If Machi is blind, then maybe the crime scene has signs that the shooter was blind (Testimony 5). But the signature could be related to his blindness. But if there's evidence that the shooter didn't need to be blind, that contradicts. Alternatively, Evidence 5 (Revolver belonging to LeTouse) suggests that the gun was LeTouse's. If Machi used it, but he's blind, how would he get the gun? But maybe he took it. Alternatively, if the Revolver was used by someone else, but the testimony says the shooter was blind (Machi), then that's consistent.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 5 (shooter was blind) and Evidence 10 (Diagram shows two bullet holes on the wall by the door). If the shooter was blind, maybe they couldn't aim accurately, leading to multiple shots. But the Revolver is a high-caliber gun.
